questiontext.text:
In the 2-vs-3 tapping exercise, we speak a steady cycle of
1–2–3–4–5–6.

What is the main reason for using this 6-count cycle?

generalfeedback.text: The 6-count provides a neutral scaffold that is long enough to express both 3-group (1–3–5) and 2-group (1–4) patterns over the same even pulse, without introducing meter or accents.

answer.text: It provides a neutral counting scaffold long enough to show both 3-group and 2-group patterns over the same even pulse.
It defines a fixed meter of 6/4 that we use for the whole course.

feedback.text: We are not defining a meter here.

answer.text: It marks strong and weak beats in a hierarchy.

feedback.text: We are not assigning strong/weak or hierarchy yet.

answer.text: It is just a random choice of numbers with no particular purpose.

feedback.text: The 6-count is chosen specifically because it accommodates both 2- and 3-groupings.

questiontext.text:
While counting 1–2–3–4–5–6 evenly, you tap one hand on
1, 3, and 5.

What type of grouping are you experiencing?

generalfeedback.text: Tapping 1–3–5 over an even 6-count creates a 3-group pattern: three equally spaced taps across six pulses.

answer.text: A grouping of 3 pulses repeated over the 6-count.
A grouping of 2 pulses repeated over the 6-count.

feedback.text: Grouping in 2 uses taps on 1 and 4.

answer.text: A random tapping pattern with no structure.

feedback.text: There is a clear structure here: equal spacing every two pulses.

answer.text: A pattern that defines a fixed meter with accents on 1, 3, and 5.

feedback.text: We are not defining meter or accent patterns at this stage.

questiontext.text:
While counting 1–2–3–4–5–6 evenly, you tap one hand on
1 and 4.

What type of grouping are you experiencing?

generalfeedback.text: Tapping 1 and 4 over six pulses creates a 2-group pattern: two equally spaced taps separated by three pulses each.

answer.text: A grouping of 2 pulses repeated over the 6-count.
A grouping of 3 pulses repeated over the 6-count.
A purely random tapping pattern.

feedback.text: There is clear regular spacing between taps.

answer.text: A pattern that necessarily implies a compound meter.

feedback.text: We are not assigning meter labels here, only grouping.

name.text: 2 vs 3 – What is the main goal?

questiontext.text: When you count 1–2–3–4–5–6 evenly, tap one hand on 1–3–5, and the other on 1–4, what is the main goal of this exercise in this course?

generalfeedback.text: The goal is to experience how two different groupings (2 and 3) can coexist over the same even pulse before introducing notation, meter, or accent hierarchy.

answer.text: To experience how 2-group and 3-group patterns interact over the same even pulse.
To memorize all possible polyrhythms used in world music.

feedback.text: This exercise is much more focused than that.

answer.text: To practice reading complex meter signatures in notation.

feedback.text: We are staying away from notation and meter here.

answer.text: To prepare directly for twelve-tone pitch rows.

feedback.text: This work will support later concepts, but that is not the immediate goal.
